'''''Leucoagaricus americanus''''' is a [[mushroom]] in the [[genus]] ''[[Leucoagaricus]]'', native to [[North America]].<ref name=rm>{{cite web|last=Rogers Mushrooms|title=Leucoagaricus americanus|url=http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6288.asp|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67aNXUf0R?url=http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6288.asp|archivedate=2012-05-11}}</ref> It was first described by [[Charles Horton Peck]], an American [[mycologist]] of the 19th and early 20th centuries, in 1869. It grows in waste places, on stumps, and the ground. It is considered [[edible mushroom|edible]], but it might be [[Mushroom poisoning|harmful]] to ingest the mushroom sometimes. {{Citation needed|date=February 2018}}

==Description==
The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is 3–15 cm and oval in shape when immature, becoming convex to flat when fully grown. The cap feels dry and smooth at the beginning, but gradually gets reddish to reddish brown scales. It is white in color but reddens with maturity or after being handled.<ref name=mkuo>Kuo, M. (2005, October). ''Leucoagaricus americanus''. Retrieved from the MushroomExpert.Com Web site: http://www.mushroomexpert.com/leucoagaricus_americanus.html</ref> The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are free from the [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]] and lie close together. They appear white when young and are stained pinkish to maroon. The stipe is 7–14 cm long, often enlarged at or below the middle and tapering toward the base. It appears white at first, staining or aging pink or reddish brown. It feels smooth with its silky hairs. The [[Biological membrane|membranous]] [[Universal veil|veil]] leaves a white double edged [[annulus (mycology)|ring]] on the upper stipe that may disappear in age.<ref name="rm"/> The [[spores]] are white to cream in color and measure 8–10 x 6–7.5 [[micrometre|µm]].<ref name="cf"/> The [[Trama (mycology)|flesh]] is white throughout. It bruises yellow to orange when young but dries reddish when mature. The [[Trama (mycology)|flesh]] is thick and discolors when cut, bruised or damaged.<ref name="rm"/>
